title: Credit Default Swaps: Insurance That Burned the House Down
description: A short lesson to help you apply Credit Default Swaps: Insurance That Burned the House Down.

hook.text: AIG sold $440 billion in insurance on mortgage bonds. When the bonds went bad, AIG couldn't pay.

buildup.text: Credit default swaps (CDS) let investors buy insurance on bonds they didn't own.

discovery.text: The CDS market grew to $62 trillion â€” unregulated, unreported, and larger than the entire world's GDP.

twist.text: When mortgages defaulted, CDS created obligations nobody could honor.

climax.text: CDS turned a housing crisis into a global financial crisis.

punchline.text: Wall Street insured itself against risk so thoroughly that it created a bigger.

quiz.question: How did credit default swaps worsen the 2008 crisis?
options: The unregulated $62 trillion CDS market amplified losses when mortgages defaulted, threatening the entire system
